segments.text: Personal log, day 89. It's late evening, most of the crew is asleep. I'm in my sleep compartment, just thinking.
Today was long. The water system repair this morning, then that media interview this afternoon. By the time I finished exercise and dinner, I was exhausted.
But I can't sleep yet. My mind is too active. Sometimes I wonder if I'm doing enough up here, if this mission really matters.
Then I remember the protein crystal experiments. If our work leads to better diabetes treatments, that could help millions of people.
That's not nothing. That's real. But it's also abstract - I'm not seeing the direct impact. I won't see those people whose lives might improve.
The interview today was interesting. Sarah asked good questions. When I talked about the overview effect, I could hear myself getting emotional.
Seeing Earth from space really does change you. Every time I look out the Cupola, I'm struck by how beautiful and fragile our planet is.
All those borders we fight over, the conflicts, the divisions - they're invisible from up here. It all looks like one connected system.
I wish everyone could see this view. Maybe then we'd take better care of what we have.
Ninety-three days left. Three more months away from Lin and Mei. I talked to them yesterday, and Mei is growing so fast.
She told me about her science test, about learning the planets. Her teacher is teaching them about Jupiter. Eight years old and already curious about space.
Part of me wonders if I'm being selfish. I chose this mission, chose to be away from my family for six months. What kind of father does that?
But then I remember why I do this. I want Mei to grow up in a world where space exploration is normal, where humanity thinks bigger than just Earth.
Maybe she'll be an astronaut someday. Or a scientist. Or maybe she'll do something completely different. The point is, she'll have options because we're pushing boundaries.
Torres and Kim did exceptional work on that EVA yesterday. Watching them outside, I felt this mix of pride and anxiety.
As commander, their safety is my responsibility. If something had gone wrong, if they'd been injured or worse - I don't know how I'd live with that.
But they were perfect. Textbook execution. That's what training does - it makes dangerous situations manageable through preparation and discipline.
I've been thinking about the water system issue this morning. Such a small thing - a loose connection - but it could have cascaded into something serious.
Up here, everything is connected. One failure can trigger others. That's why we're so meticulous about maintenance, so careful about procedures.
There's no calling a plumber when you're orbiting at 27,000 kilometers per hour. We have to be self-sufficient, ready to fix anything.
Sometimes I think about what early astronauts went through. The Apollo missions, the Shuttle program - we stand on their shoulders.
They took bigger risks with less technology. We have it easier in many ways, but the fundamental challenge remains the same.
Humans aren't built for space. We're evolved for gravity, atmosphere, magnetic field protection. Being up here is fundamentally unnatural.
But we adapt. That's what humans do. We figure out how to survive in environments that should kill us.
Mars will be the ultimate test of that. If we can establish a permanent presence there, it'll prove that humanity can become a multi-planetary species.
I probably won't go to Mars. I'll be too old by the time those missions launch. But maybe I'm helping pave the way for whoever does go.
Every experiment we run, every system we test, every problem we solve - it's all data for future missions. We're building the knowledge base.
It's quiet right now. I can hear the ventilation system humming, the occasional beep from monitoring equipment. These sounds have become familiar.
In three months, I'll be back on Earth. I'll hear rain, wind, birds, traffic. Right now, those sounds seem alien even though I lived with them my whole life.
The readjustment is going to be hard. Not just physically - though that'll be brutal - but mentally and emotionally too.
How do you go back to normal life after seeing Earth from this perspective? After floating for six months? After being part of something this significant?
I guess I'll figure it out. Astronauts before me have done it. They've returned, readjusted, found meaning in normal life again.
Alright, I should try to sleep. Tomorrow's schedule is packed - more experiments, a communications test, regular maintenance checks.
The work continues. That's what this is about - the work, the mission, the progress we're making for all of humanity.
End personal log.

environment.background_sounds: quiet ventilation, equipment beeping, station creaking
